But you omit how thin the margin for error becomes from here: any macro shock—say interest rates holding higher, inflation surprise, or adverse regulatory news—could knock the stock 5-10% more easily than it rises 5-8%.  

My view remains that while a modest increase into January is plausible, the upside beyond ~5-8% is constrained; downside risk—5-15% from present levels—is materially larger.

You say: “guidance being disclosed does not imply the market fully priced in all upside” — but you ignore that Apple’s 10-12% holiday-quarter revenue growth and double-digit iPhone growth was *well above* Wall Street’s prior ~6% estimates. ([axios.com](https://www.axios.com/2025/10/30/apple-q4-2025-earnings-stock-iphone?utm_source=openai)) That means much of the upside is already baked in, leaving little room for further surprise.

You claim: “record installed device base … strong services growth … favorable mix and more services/goods profitability” will rescue the stock from downside. However, recent data shows that while services/gross margins are high (≈75% for services vs ~35–40% for hardware) ([9to5mac.com](https://9to5mac.com/2025/05/02/apple-gross-margin-on-services-record-high/?utm_source=openai)), sales in Greater China—a key region—have slipped, and local rivals (Huawei, Xiaomi) are regaining market share amid regulatory hurdles. ([livemint.com](https://www.livemint.com/technology/tech-news/apples-ai-delay-regulatory-pressure-undermine-china-market-position-11746192009587.html?utm_source=openai)) That puts a ceiling on how much services can offset hardware headwinds, especially if China stays weak.

Also, you minimize macro risk. But consider what the ECB and other authorities are warning: tech valuations are “stretched” amid FOMO, and any inflation surprise or prolonged high interest rates could trigger sharp corrections. ([ft.com](https://www.ft.com/content/82100215-18d0-4850-8dcd-d9745ad342d0?utm_source=openai)) Regulatory risk is rising too—Apple faces potential $38 billion fines in India for new antitrust laws, and App Store compliance in China is under scrutiny. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/sustainability/boards-policy-regulation/apple-contests-indias-antitrust-penalty-law-with-risk-38-billion-fine-filing-2025-11-26/?utm_source=openai))

In short: the positives you cite are real, but mostly already priced in. Meanwhile, the risks (China softness, regulatory fines, macroeconomic tightening) create a more asymmetric risk profile. I maintain that upside is capped at about +5–8%, whereas downside of -5–15% over this time frame looks materially more plausible.

You said **“you ignore that Apple’s 10-12% holiday-quarter revenue growth … was well above Wall Street’s prior ~6% estimates”** and **“analysts like Dan Ives have raised price targets to $325 … that implies another ~10-15% from current levels”**. But those arguments both rest on expectations that *are already baked in*, and on optimistic forecasts that conflict with broader signals of risk. Here’s why:

1. You ignore that Apple **guidance explicitly set expectations at 10-12% revenue growth** for December, meaning the market has already priced that in substantially. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-december-quarter-projection/?utm_source=openai)) When expectations are already high, there's little left to push the stock materially higher unless actual performance significantly *exceeds* guidance—which is far from guaranteed given supply constraints and China weakness. So the ~10-12% upside you project depends on beating what investors already expect.

2. You claim that the surge to ~US$325 price targets (Dan Ives, Bernstein) supports **“another ~10–15% from current levels”**. However, Analyst consensus—reflected in MarketBeat and TipRanks—shows the average 12-month targets are around **US$278-$294**, implying very modest upside or even mild downside from current levels (~US$286). ([tipranks.com](https://www.tipranks.com/stocks/aapl/forecast?utm_source=openai)) Those higher targets are outliers—while the median/consensus implies anything much above +5% would require strong surprises.

Given all that, I stick with my position: Apple is far more likely to *decline modestly* or move sideways from December 2, 2025 to January 1, 2026. Upside is capped—+5-8% is aggressive—and downside of -5-15% is materially more plausible, especially if macro headwinds persist, China disappoints, or regulatory risk escalates.

You said **“you reaffirmed that Apple stock is far more likely to increase … +8% to +12% … potential to reach +15%”**, but you ignore the asymmetric risk profile baked in by stiff macro headwinds and valuations that already reflect much of the upside. Here’s why +15% is unlikely—and why downside, perhaps –5 to –10%, is more plausible.

---

## 1. Macro Risks Are Tightening, Not Easing

You claim “macro risks … unless a severe regulatory or macro event hits … probability of a large drop is lower.” However:

- The OECD warns of a *slowdown in U.S. growth*—forecasted fall from about 2% in 2025 to 1.7% in 2026—driven by lingering inflation, a weakening labor market, and tariff effects. ([axios.com](https://www.axios.com/2025/12/02/ai-bubble-stock-market-forecast-oecd?utm_source=openai))  
- Similarly, BlackRock raised alarm about rising interest rates, driven by mounting AI investment and increased borrowing, adding “upward pressure on interest rates amid already high levels of U.S. national debt.” ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/business/blackrock-turns-bearish-long-term-treasuries-ai-funding-wave-looms-2025-12-02/?utm_source=openai))  

These suggest that the cost of equity is likely to stay elevated, tightening valuations—especially for growth names like Apple.

---

## 2. Valuations Appear Stretched; Much of Good News Is Already Priced In

You note “current margins are expanding … services up … product mix favorable … cash flows huge,” but:

- Apple’s Q4 2025 gross margin was already 47.2%, up ~70 basis points YoY, with guidance only nudging it to 47–48% in December. That leaves limited margin expansion left to drive further upside. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-4q-2025-earnings/?utm_source=openai))  
- The “Singles’ Day” news—iPhone 17 taking 26% share in China while other brands fell—is strong, but it is already widely cited by markets as evidence Apple is executing on its guidance. It’s **not** a surprising beat for investors who already expect strong China performance this quarter. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/china/apple-single-handedly-drives-singles-day-smartphone-sales-growth-2025-11-27/?utm_source=openai))  

So while these data points are positive, they seem incorporated into guidance already (10–12% revenue growth; best holiday quarter) ([alphaspread.com](https://www.alphaspread.com/security/nasdaq/aapl/investor-relations/earnings-call/q4-2025?utm_source=openai)). That means the “surprise” margin for upside is quite thin.

---

## 3. Risks Outweigh Upside Going Into Early January

You claim “gain of around **10-12%** is the most probable outcome, with potential up to +15%.” Here’s why that overstates the odds:

- Supply constraints on iPhone 17 remain for certain models; Apple itself said it’s unclear when supply and demand will balance. These constraints cap upside for holiday-quarter sales. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-4q-2025-earnings/?utm_source=openai))  
- China revenue was down ~4% year-over-year in the September quarter—even with strong Singles’ Day results—pointing to broader consumer weakness and a tough compare across years. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/q4-2025-earnings-call-takeaways/?utm_source=openai))  
- Elevated tariff‐related costs (~$1.1–$1.4 billion) and increasing R&D/OpEx (especially AI investments) add expense pressure, which will eat into margins and reduce earnings surprises. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-4q-2025-earnings/?utm_source=openai))  

---

## Reinforcing My Position

I remain convinced that Apple stock is more likely to see modest gains or a decline from December 2, 2025 to January 1, 2026—**something like –5% to +8% is more realistic**, with the more probable outcome tilted toward the lower end. The market has already priced in much of the good news. Given high interest rates, stretched tech valuations, China weakness, and near-term supply constraints, the “headline upside” you forecast is unlikely to materialize.

You said “you ignore that Apple’s 10–12% holiday-quarter revenue growth … was *well above* Wall Street’s prior ~6% estimates”—but you ignore that Apple’s guidance explicitly expects 10–12% revenue growth for the December quarter. That means investors already see the +10–12% as the baseline, leaving much less room for the stock to rally sharply *solely* on guidance. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/q4-2025-earnings-call-takeaways/?utm_source=openai))

You claim “record installed device base … strong services growth … favorable mix … will rescue the stock from downside,” yet you admit that “Greater China sales have slipped … down 3.6% year over year” in the latest quarter. That region is huge for Apple, and any sustained weakness there offsets much of the services tailwinds. ([finance.yahoo.com](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/apple-q4-earnings-beat-estimates-172000528.html?utm_source=openai))

Here’s why I still strongly expect **+8-12% upside** from Dec. 2, 2025 to Jan. 1, 2026:

- Apple just posted **$102.5B revenue up 8% YoY**, with services up **~15.1%** and gross margins expanding — showing both demand and profitability momentum. ([finance.yahoo.com](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/apple-q4-earnings-beat-estimates-172000528.html?utm_source=openai))  
- The company guided for its best December quarter ever, expecting 10-12% revenue growth and double-digit iPhone growth. Those expectations, plus strong Singles’ Day iPhone 17 demand in China (26% share during the event) give a seasonal tailwind. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/q4-2025-earnings-call-takeaways/?utm_source=openai))  
- Analysts like Dan Ives have raised price targets to **$325**, factoring in the upcoming AI cycle and hardware strength. That implies another ~10–15% from current levels (assuming Apple is near ~$280). ([nasdaq.com](https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/6-investing-experts-predict-how-high-apple-stock-will-go-2025?utm_source=openai))  

Given all this, downside risks (China softness, regulatory pressure, valuation concerns) are real—but mostly expected and already discounted. So the asymmetric scenario favors upside. Over this one-month period, a gain of **8-12%** is not just plausible, it’s the most likely outcome.

conversation_log.speaker: Con Position
conversation_log.content:
You said **“you ignore that Apple’s 10-12% holiday-quarter revenue growth … was well above Wall Street’s prior ~6% estimates”** and **“analysts like Dan Ives have raised price targets to $325 … that implies another ~10-15% from current levels”**. But those arguments both rest on expectations that *are already baked in*, and on optimistic forecasts that conflict with broader signals of risk. Here’s why:

1. You ignore that Apple **guidance explicitly set expectations at 10-12% revenue growth** for December, meaning the market has already priced that in substantially. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-december-quarter-projection/?utm_source=openai)) When expectations are already high, there's little left to push the stock materially higher unless actual performance significantly *exceeds* guidance—which is far from guaranteed given supply constraints and China weakness. So the ~10-12% upside you project depends on beating what investors already expect.

2. You claim that the surge to ~US$325 price targets (Dan Ives, Bernstein) supports **“another ~10–15% from current levels”**. However, Analyst consensus—reflected in MarketBeat and TipRanks—shows the average 12-month targets are around **US$278-$294**, implying very modest upside or even mild downside from current levels (~US$286). ([tipranks.com](https://www.tipranks.com/stocks/aapl/forecast?utm_source=openai)) Those higher targets are outliers—while the median/consensus implies anything much above +5% would require strong surprises.

Given all that, I stick with my position: Apple is far more likely to *decline modestly* or move sideways from December 2, 2025 to January 1, 2026. Upside is capped—+5-8% is aggressive—and downside of -5-15% is materially more plausible, especially if macro headwinds persist, China disappoints, or regulatory risk escalates.

conversation_log.speaker: Pro Position
conversation_log.content:
You said: **“you ignore that Apple’s 10-12% holiday-quarter revenue growth … was well above Wall Street’s prior ~6% estimates”**, and “you claim that the surge to ~$325 price targets … implies another ~10–15% from current levels”. But you overstate what the data supports—and here’s why those arguments don’t justify expecting more than ~10-12% upside between Dec 2, 2025 and Jan 1, 2026.

---

### 1. Guidance expectations are *already baked in*, but upside is not unlimited

You argue that *because Apple guided for 10-12% revenue growth,* the stock can rise 10-15%. However, the guidance itself already sets the market’s baseline. In Apple’s Q4 fiscal 2025, revenue came in at ~$102.5B (up ~8% YoY), with services up ~15.1% YoY. ([zacks.com](https://www.zacks.com/stock/news/2782859/apple-q4-earnings-beat-estimates-services-drive-top-line-growth?utm_source=openai)) The company forecasted growing total revenue by **10-12% YoY** in the December quarter, with double-digit iPhone revenue growth. ([nasdaq.com](https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/apple-q4-earnings-beat-estimates-services-drive-top-line-growth?utm_source=openai)) Investors already priced that in by early November, so expecting much more without exceptional overperformance is speculative.

---

### 2. Stellar China results bolster upside

You claim that Apple’s upside is modest, but *you ignore* the strong hardware momentum—especially in China—which provides tangible levers for beating even optimistic expectations. 

- During the recent Singles’ Day festival, Apple’s iPhone 17 captured **26% of all Chinese smartphone sales**, pushing total smartphone sales up 3% YoY, when sales *excluding Apple* fell 5%. ([investing.com](https://www.investing.com/news/stock-market-news/apple-singlehandedly-drives-singles-day-smartphone-sales-growth-4380976?utm_source=openai))  
- Product mix, upgraded pricing, and promotional success (e.g. discounts on Pro models) have further amplified that performance. ([investing.com](https://www.investing.com/news/stock-market-news/apple-iphone-dominates-china-singles-day-event-rivals-struggle--counterpoint-4381362?utm_source=openai))  

These are not fringe anecdotes—they’re material drivers that could allow Apple to exceed guidance, thus pushing stock even higher over December.

---

### 3. Valuation headwinds are real, but not decisive in the short term

You said that valuations and macro risks “make downside of -5-15% materially more plausible”. But current margins are expanding (gross margin at 47.2%, up 100 basis points YoY), service margins, product mix favorable, and cash flows remain huge. ([zacks.com](https://www.zacks.com/stock/news/2782859/apple-q4-earnings-beat-estimates-services-drive-top-line-growth?utm_source=openai)) Risks like tariffs are known, and unless a severe regulatory or macro event hits, much of the downside is already in current pricing. Also—strong holiday sales tend to compress risk sentiment, so the probability of a large drop is lower between early December and early January.

---

### My position: 2025/12/2 to 2026/1/1 outlook

Given all that, I reaffirm that Apple stock is far more likely to *increase* in that period. A reasonable range is **+8% to +12%**, with potential to reach +15% if China demand or iPhone 17 sales significantly outperform expectations. A mild downside (~-5%) is possible only if a surprise negative signal emerges (e.g. sharp macro shock or persistent supply constraints), which currently seems unlikely given the data.

So overall: a gain of around **10-12%** is the most probable outcome.

conversation_log.speaker: Con Position
conversation_log.content:
You said **“you reaffirmed that Apple stock is far more likely to increase … +8% to +12% … potential to reach +15%”**, but you ignore the asymmetric risk profile baked in by stiff macro headwinds and valuations that already reflect much of the upside. Here’s why +15% is unlikely—and why downside, perhaps –5 to –10%, is more plausible.

---

## 1. Macro Risks Are Tightening, Not Easing

You claim “macro risks … unless a severe regulatory or macro event hits … probability of a large drop is lower.” However:

- The OECD warns of a *slowdown in U.S. growth*—forecasted fall from about 2% in 2025 to 1.7% in 2026—driven by lingering inflation, a weakening labor market, and tariff effects. ([axios.com](https://www.axios.com/2025/12/02/ai-bubble-stock-market-forecast-oecd?utm_source=openai))  
- Similarly, BlackRock raised alarm about rising interest rates, driven by mounting AI investment and increased borrowing, adding “upward pressure on interest rates amid already high levels of U.S. national debt.” ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/business/blackrock-turns-bearish-long-term-treasuries-ai-funding-wave-looms-2025-12-02/?utm_source=openai))  

These suggest that the cost of equity is likely to stay elevated, tightening valuations—especially for growth names like Apple.

---

## 2. Valuations Appear Stretched; Much of Good News Is Already Priced In

You note “current margins are expanding … services up … product mix favorable … cash flows huge,” but:

- Apple’s Q4 2025 gross margin was already 47.2%, up ~70 basis points YoY, with guidance only nudging it to 47–48% in December. That leaves limited margin expansion left to drive further upside. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-4q-2025-earnings/?utm_source=openai))  
- The “Singles’ Day” news—iPhone 17 taking 26% share in China while other brands fell—is strong, but it is already widely cited by markets as evidence Apple is executing on its guidance. It’s **not** a surprising beat for investors who already expect strong China performance this quarter. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/china/apple-single-handedly-drives-singles-day-smartphone-sales-growth-2025-11-27/?utm_source=openai))  

So while these data points are positive, they seem incorporated into guidance already (10–12% revenue growth; best holiday quarter) ([alphaspread.com](https://www.alphaspread.com/security/nasdaq/aapl/investor-relations/earnings-call/q4-2025?utm_source=openai)). That means the “surprise” margin for upside is quite thin.

---

## 3. Risks Outweigh Upside Going Into Early January

You claim “gain of around **10-12%** is the most probable outcome, with potential up to +15%.” Here’s why that overstates the odds:

- Supply constraints on iPhone 17 remain for certain models; Apple itself said it’s unclear when supply and demand will balance. These constraints cap upside for holiday-quarter sales. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-4q-2025-earnings/?utm_source=openai))  
- China revenue was down ~4% year-over-year in the September quarter—even with strong Singles’ Day results—pointing to broader consumer weakness and a tough compare across years. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/q4-2025-earnings-call-takeaways/?utm_source=openai))  
- Elevated tariff‐related costs (~$1.1–$1.4 billion) and increasing R&D/OpEx (especially AI investments) add expense pressure, which will eat into margins and reduce earnings surprises. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-4q-2025-earnings/?utm_source=openai))  

---

## Reinforcing My Position

I remain convinced that Apple stock is more likely to see modest gains or a decline from December 2, 2025 to January 1, 2026—**something like –5% to +8% is more realistic**, with the more probable outcome tilted toward the lower end. The market has already priced in much of the good news. Given high interest rates, stretched tech valuations, China weakness, and near-term supply constraints, the “headline upside” you forecast is unlikely to materialize.

final_report:
Research Question & Context  
-----------------------------  
What is the likely percentage change in Apple Inc.’s stock price between December 2, 2025 and January 1, 2026, given recent company performance, guidance, and macroeconomic conditions? This question arises in the context of Apple’s strong Q4 fiscal 2025 results (ended September 27, 2025), its projections for the fiscal December quarter, and mixed but critical risks such as China revenue performance, supply constraints, and valuation pressures.

Summary of Viewpoints  
----------------------  

**Pro-Upside Argument**  
- Apple delivered Q4 FY2025 revenue of **$102.5 billion**, up ~8% year over year, alongside record results for iPhone and Services revenue; guidance for the December (holiday) quarter anticipates **10–12% revenue growth**, with double-digit growth in iPhone revenue. ([apple.com](https://www.apple.com/sn/newsroom/2025/10/apple-reports-fourth-quarter-results/?utm_source=openai))  
- During China’s Singles’ Day shopping festival, Apple’s iPhone 17 lineup captured **26% of smartphone sales** across brands—helping overall smartphone sales rise while others declined; this suggests strong momentum in China. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/china/apple-single-handedly-drives-singles-day-smartphone-sales-growth-2025-11-27/?utm_source=openai))  
- Gross margins are expanding (corporate margin ~47.2%), services continue to grow at ~15% YoY—both contributing higher-margin revenue. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-4q-2025-earnings/?utm_source=openai))  
- Based on these, pro-positioners expect Apple stock to rise by **8-12%** over the December to January period, with an optimistic ceiling near **+15%** if Apple exceeds guidance significantly.  

**Con-Downside Argument**  
- Much of the positive guidance (10–12% revenue growth for December quarter, double-digit iPhone growth) appears priced into current valuations, limiting potential upside unless Apple beats these already ambitious expectations. ([alphaspread.com](https://www.alphaspread.com/security/nasdaq/aapl/investor-relations/earnings-call/q4-2025?utm_source=openai))  
- Greater China revenue was down ~3.6% year over year in the September quarter; supply constraints on iPhone 16/17 models may limit profit conversion of demand. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-4q-2025-earnings/?utm_source=openai))  
- Valuations are stretched; macro risks—interest rate persistence, inflation surprises, regulatory actions (tariffs, antitrust)—could trigger downside. Expected upside is more modest, maybe **+5-8%**, while downside risks might bring a drop of up to **5-15%**.  

Comparative Analysis & Key Conflicts  
-------------------------------------  

| Conflict | Pro-View | Con-View | Concrete Example |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Are expectations already priced in?** | Pro argues that guidance (10–12% growth) exceeds prior Wall Street expectations (~6%), leaving room for surprise upside. ([ft.com](https://www.ft.com/content/7e4e5c42-6b67-4e92-aaec-4c5714f672f6?utm_source=openai)) | Con contends that guidance has been fully—or largely—priced in; further gains need actual results beyond that already baked into projections. |
| **Strength in China vs China as risk** | Pro interprets Singles Day dominance (26% share) as evidence China momentum will drive unexpected upside. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/china/apple-single-handedly-drives-singles-day-smartphone-sales-growth-2025-11-27/?utm_source=openai)) | Con counters that overall China revenue was down ~4%, and that challenges (regulatory, competitive) remain unresolved. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-4q-2025-earnings/?utm_source=openai)) |
| **Magnitude of possible upside vs downside** | Pro believes +8-12% gain is most likely, possible +15% in bullish scenarios. | Con limits upside to +5-8%, argues downside (−5 to −15%) is more plausible in risk-heavy environment. |

Tentative Conclusion & Recommendation  
----------------------------------------  

Given the evidence, an informed investor should lean toward expecting a modest **gain** in Apple stock over the period from **December 2, 2025 to January 1, 2026**, likely in the range of **+5% to +10%**. A rise toward +12% is plausible but would likely require strong holiday demand, minimal supply disruptions, and favorable macroeconomic signals. Conversely, a downside of around **5%** is possible if negative surprises emerge—such as China remaining weak, tariff/regulatory escalation, or macro shocks—but a drop of −10 to −15% is unlikely unless multiple risk events converge.  

Recommendation: Investors seeking exposure may consider positioning for this moderate upside but should hedge against downside risk—e.g. by emphasizing sectors less sensitive to international exposure or interest rates, or using options to protect equity positions.

Limitations & Suggestions for Further Investigation  
------------------------------------------------------  

This assessment relies on guidance and recent performance data but cannot account for all possible shocks—such as sudden regulatory rulings, global economic slowdowns, or unexpected supply‐chain disruptions. Calendar events like Chinese New Year timing, unanticipated inflation data, or geopolitical issues could shift outcomes materially.  

Further investigation could include scenario modeling (bull, base, bear) with assigned probabilities; detailed sensitivity analysis for assumptions like growth in China, impact of tariffs or China regulation, margin compressions; and tracking analyst revisions and investor sentiment closer to late December to see whether upside remains underappreciated or becomes fully priced.

References  
----------  
- Apple’s Q4 FY2025 results: $102.5 B revenue (8% YoY), EPS $1.85, services up ~15% YoY; gross margin 47.2 %. ([apple.com](https://www.apple.com/sn/newsroom/2025/10/apple-reports-fourth-quarter-results/?utm_source=openai))  
- Guidance for December quarter: 10-12% revenue growth, double-digit iPhone growth, best‐ever quarter expected. ([alphaspread.com](https://www.alphaspread.com/security/nasdaq/aapl/investor-relations/earnings-call/q4-2025?utm_source=openai))  
- China Singles Day: iPhone 17 captured 26% of smartphone sales in China during Singles Day, helping offset declines from other brands. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/world/china/apple-single-handedly-drives-singles-day-smartphone-sales-growth-2025-11-27/?utm_source=openai))  
- Weakness in Greater China in Q4: ~3.6-4% YoY revenue decline. ([macrumors.com](https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/30/apple-4q-2025-earnings/?utm_source=openai))  
- Analysts’ forecasts: some targets as high as ~$320; many suggest more modest growth. ([businessinsider.com](https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-q4-earnings-report-preview-beat-iphone-demand-2025-10?utm_source=openai))
